docs.lead_paragraph: The television show ''West Wing'' picks up its story line tomorrow, extending a fictional plot based on a genuine problem -- the long history of hidden illness in the White House. ''West Wing'' President Josiah Bartlet has multiple sclerosis, a chronic neurological ailment that the first lady, a physician, has treated secretly during Mr. Bartlet's first term. Multiple sclerosis is usually not fatal, though it is often disabling. But it has not hampered Mr. Bartlet's work.

headline.main: Very Real Questions for Fictional President

docs.abstract: Long history of hidden illness in White House discussed in light of fictional plot of television show West Wing, in which president is being treated secretly for chronic neurological ailment; Aaron Sorkin, series creator, says he was only vaguely aware of history of presidential illness and had no specific leader in mind when he wrote character's illness into plot (M)
docs.snippet: The television show ''West Wing'' picks up its story line tomorrow, extending a fictional plot based on a genuine problem -- the long history of hidden illness in the White House.    ''West Wing'' President Josiah Bartlet has multiple sclerosis, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: The prescription pain relievers Vioxx and Celebrex surged onto the scene two years ago with an unprecedented marketing effort by their makers and an avalanche of sales. Patients demanded the drugs. And doctors took out their prescription pads, often not even trying to dissuade people who would have done just as well with a cheap alternative, like acetaminophen or aspirin. Tens of millions of prescriptions have been written, and the drugs remain wildly popular. But now there are troubling questions about whether Vioxx may have an unexpected side effect -- a very slight increase in the risk of heart attack.

headline.main: For Pain Reliever, Questions of Risk Remain Unresolved

docs.abstract: Uncertainty continues over whether arthritis pain relievers Vioxx and Celebrex slightly increase risk of heart attack; wildly popular drugs, known as cox-2 inhibitors, were developed to avoid stomach pain and ulcers that occur in small percentage of people using other anti-inflammatory drugs; could possibly shift biochemical balance so blood is more likely to clot; study linking Vioxx to slightly higher heart attack rate is inconclusive and no negative results have been found for Celebrex; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The prescription pain relievers Vioxx and Celebrex surged onto the scene two years ago with an unprecedented marketing effort by their makers and an avalanche of sales. Patients demanded the drugs. And doctors took out their prescription pads, often...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some art provokes strong reactions across the centuries -- especially if it was made with eggs. A letter in The New England Journal of Medicine last week described the case of a young woman in Spain who suddenly developed a severe worsening of her asthma, which had been under control. Previously, she had been hospitalized for a strong allergic reaction to eggs, and had improved after switching to an egg-free diet.

headline.main: What Came First, the Asthma or the Egg?

docs.abstract: Doctors in Spain report dust from old cathedral under renovation worsens asthma of patients allergic to eggs; note eggs have been added to paste used to protect stone buildings since Roman times; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Some art provokes strong reactions across the centuries -- especially if it was made with eggs.    A letter in The New England Journal of Medicine last week described the case of a young woman in Spain who suddenly developed a severe worsening of her...

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors often do a poor job of taking care of their own health. In a new article in The British Medical Journal, doctors attributed this to the difficulties of living up to their own expectations, as well as those of their patients and colleagues. Researchers from Queen's University of Belfast conducted a series of focus groups involving 27 primary care physicians in Northern Ireland. The doctors who took part talked about the pressure to appear healthy. One source of pressure came from patients, or rather, from the doctors' beliefs about patients' thinking. As one put it, ''Nobody wants to go and see a doctor who is sick.''
docs.abstract: Doctors in Northern Ireland taking part in focus groups admit doing poor job of taking care of their own health, which they attribute to pressure to appear healthy and pressure to work even when ill to avoid adding to colleagues' load; cite discomfort and embarrassment at being patients; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors often do a poor job of taking care of their own health. In a new article in The British Medical Journal, doctors attributed this to the difficulties of living up to their own expectations, as well as those of their patients and colleagues.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: German researchers announced last week that they had cured hepatitis C in 42 of 44 patients who were treated in the earliest stages of the disease. The finding was considered so important that an article about it was made public ahead of schedule by the editors of The New England Journal of Medicine. And the study was received with enthusiasm by specialists in hepatitis C, a viral disease that infects about 30,000 Americans a year and that has become the leading cause of liver transplants in the United States.

headline.main: Treatment of Early-Stage Hepatitis C Advances

docs.abstract: German researchers report curing hepatitis C in 42 of 44 patients treated in disease's earliest stages with drug interferon alfa-2b; experts, noting high cure rate depends on early detection, says doctors should screen people more often for disease; photo (M)
docs.snippet: German researchers announced last week that they had cured hepatitis C in 42 of 44 patients who were treated in the earliest stages of the disease.    The finding was considered so important that an article about it was made public ahead of schedule...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bean-bag weapons used by the Los Angeles police to subdue violent or disturbed people have caused a broad range of serious injuries, researchers are reporting. Many police departments have turned to bean bags as a nonlethal means of subduing people. The bean bag is a fabric pouch containing 1.4 ounces of shotgun pellets, stuffed into a shotgun shell. The bag is designed to spread out in flight to a diameter of about 10 inches and hit with about twice the force of a major league fastball.
docs.abstract: Study finds bean-bag weapons used by Los Angeles police to subdue violent or disturbed people have caused broad range of serious injuries; finds weapons, which fire fabric pouch of shotgun pellets stuffed into shotgun shell are often fired at much closer range than recommended; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Bean-bag weapons used by the Los Angeles police to subdue violent or disturbed people have caused a broad range of serious injuries, researchers are reporting.     Many police departments have turned to bean bags as a nonlethal means of subduing...

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation is quickly buying up stocks of gas masks, shelves are being stripped of antibiotics, and bottled water may not be far behind. Many travelers have canceled trips by air and taken trains or cars instead, even across the country. New Yorkers fearful of an attack on the subways insist on riding in cars on traffic-choked streets. Doctors in Boston report that patients with minor ailments like colds and sore throats have been calling out of fear that they may have been sickened by a toxic chemical or lethal germ introduced by terrorists.

headline.main: Don't Lose Sight of Real, Everyday Risks

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on concern that irrational preoccupation with terrorist threat will divert people from responding to real and immediate risks to well-being; cites health risks over which people can exercise control (M)
docs.snippet: The nation is quickly buying up stocks of gas masks, shelves are being stripped of  antibiotics, and bottled water may not be far behind. Many travelers have canceled trips by air and taken trains or cars instead, even across the country. New Yorkers...

docs.lead_paragraph: The percentage of mothers who breast-fed their newborns jumped at a Boston hospital when it introduced a 10-step plan that had been widely used overseas to encourage breast-feeding and cut down on formula use, according to a new study in the journal Pediatrics. Health experts say breast milk is the best food for most infants. The article described the efforts of Boston Medical Center to adopt the guidelines set by the Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative, a campaign begun in 1991 by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund. More than 31,000 sites worldwide have qualified for the ''Baby Friendly'' designation by successfully adopting 10 rules that focus on training of staff, pregnant women and new mothers; encouraging breast-feeding through steps like keeping babies in their mothers' rooms; and discouraging bottle feeding and the use of pacifiers.
docs.abstract: Study finds percentage of mothers who breast-fed their newborns jumped from 58 percent to 86.5 percent at Boston Medical Center when hospital introduced 10-step plan widely used overseas to encourage breast-feeding and cut down on formula use (M)
docs.snippet: The percentage of mothers who breast-fed their newborns jumped at a Boston hospital when it introduced a 10-step plan that had been widely used overseas to encourage breast-feeding and cut down on formula use, according to a new study in the journal...

docs.lead_paragraph: People submerged in cold water in accidents can sometimes be revived and recover even after periods of unconsciousness that would have caused death or brain damage if they had not been chilled. Researchers have begun exploring whether they can use this protective effect of chilling. A team from Sweden last year reported in a study that cooling lowered the death rate in stroke victims.
docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Texas-Houston Medical Center reduce body temperature of nine people who suffered heart attacks in which they were without pulse for average of 11 minutes; four survive, three of them without apparent brain damage (S)
docs.snippet: People submerged in cold water in accidents can sometimes be revived and recover even after periods of unconsciousness that would have caused death or brain damage if they had not been chilled.     Researchers have begun exploring whether they can...

docs.lead_paragraph: Henry Cavendish discovered hydrogen, weighed the earth and investigated the powerful electric shocks delivered by the torpedo fish. An 18th-century Englishman, Cavendish was known as widely for his oddity as for his accomplishments. Reclusive and detached, he published little, never married, dressed shabbily, appeared oblivious to his wealth and spoke rarely. He ''probably uttered fewer words in the course of his life than any man who ever lived to fourscore years, not at all excepting the monks of La Trappe,'' a contemporary is said to have remarked.
docs.abstract: Dr Oliver Sacks, writing in journal Neurology, suggests that Henry Cavendish, eccentric 18th-century English scientist, suffered from Asperger's syndrome; notes psychiatric syndrome, thought related to autism, involves severe impairment in social interaction and development of restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests and activities; photo (M)
